SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings using context, affixes, or reference materials.
Content: Read the sentences from the passage.

:ibox:When we arrived at the classroom, an o͟b͟n͟o͟x͟i͟o͟u͟s student by the name of Ethan stood in the doorway. “Password?”

“Tolman,” I said, glancing behind Ethan. Ethan turned, thinking our teacher had entered through the other door. This gave Philo and me enough room to slip past him. Ethan growled at being tricked and pursued us.
What does the word o͟b͟n͟o͟x͟i͟o͟u͟s mean?

A.Choice: careless

B.Choice: industrious

C.Choice: playful

D.Choice: unpleasant

SubTopics: Draw conclusions, infer, and analyze by citing the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which sentences BEST develop the idea that Philo is a talented scientist in spite of his young age? Choose TWO answers.

:MC-A: Our chemistry teacher, Mr. Tolman, always approved of Philo’s crazy theories. :MC-B: Well, maybe they weren’t completely crazy. :MC-C: Last year, when he was only 13 years old, Philo won a national competition for inventing a magnetized tamperproof lock that no criminal could crack. :MC-D: This year, Mr. Tolman promoted Philo to senior chemistry with us older kids. :MC-E: Since I’m the only girl in the class, Philo and I formed a friendship over being different from the others.

SubTopics: Using appropriate text, determine the theme(s) of a text and analyze its development over the course of a text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Which statement BEST states a theme of the passage?

A.Choice: People are sometimes unaware that they are witnessing history.

B.Choice: People without much in common can still be good friends.

C.Choice: Some inventions are more fun than useful in everyday life.

D.Choice: Inventors usually fail many times before they succeed.

Content: Which excerpt from the passage BEST supports the answer to part A?

A.Choice: Since I’m the only girl in the class, Philo and I formed a friendship over being different from the others.

B.Choice: “Let’s see. What did you turn electric this time? First there was the washing machine, then the sewing machine... you make an electric horse?”

C.Choice: “Every time I hear a radio, I keep thinking, wouldn’t it be phenomenal if we could see the people we are hearing?”

D.Choice: Many years later, we all realized that we had been a part of something amazing that day: the birth of television, brought to life by an inventive Utah farm boy named Philo Farnsworth.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings using context, affixes, or reference materials.
Content: Based on the “Philo Farnsworth Time Line,” which event occurred soon after the events that are described in the passage?

A.Choice: Philo applied for a patent for barn lights.

B.Choice: Philo was named the winner of a national contest.

C.Choice: Philo finished designing an early version of a television.

D.Choice: Philo sold his television design to an electronics company.

SubTopics: Develop narratives including poems about real or imagined experiences which establish and maintain a consistent point of view and include clearly identified characters, well-structured event sequences, narrative techniques, and relevant descriptive details.
Content: “The Birth of Television” mentions that an American electronics company called RCA purchased licenses from Philo to use his television design. Think about what may have happened when Philo presented his television design to the people at this company.

Write a narrative for your teacher about Philo presenting his ideas to a group of people at RCA. Be sure to use narrative elements such as sensory details, dialogue, figurative language, and description as they are appropriate in your writing. Use details and information from the passage in your narrative.

:ibox:Writer’s Checklist

• My narrative has an effective beginning, middle, and end.
• My narrative flows smoothly from one idea to another.
• My narrative develops plot, character(s), and setting.
• My narrative includes specific and relevant details, reasons, and/or examples.
• My narrative uses precise and vivid language.
• My narrative contains sentences that are clear and varied in structure.
• My narrative includes correct grammar, usage, punctuation, capitalization, and spelling.
• My narrative uses material from the source(s).

SubTopics: Analyze how literary devices are used to develop setting, reveal character, advance the plot, and contribute to meaning.
Content: How do the author’s descriptions of the setting, Patrick, and Kip in the opening paragraph contribute to the overall meaning of the passage? Choose TWO answers.

A.Choice: They establish how important baseball is to Patrick and Kip.

B.Choice: They focus attention on the relationship between Patrick and Kip.

C.Choice: They establish the ages of Patrick and Kip in order to provide context for the story.

D.Choice: They foreshadow the points of view that Patrick and Kip will have when John chooses not to practice with them.

E.Choice: They highlight the time of year in which the story takes place so that it is clear why Patrick and Kip are playing baseball.

SubTopics: Using appropriate text, determine the theme(s) of a text and analyze its development over the course of a text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Which sentence describes a theme in the passage?

A.Choice: When faced with opposition, people should stay true to what they value.

B.Choice: People can remain friends even when they have different interests.

C.Choice: With enough work, a person can accomplish any goal.

D.Choice: Staying informed about current events is important.

Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST supports the answer to part A?

A.Choice: Before they got to the schoolyard, the two stopped by another friend’s house to see if he wanted to practice with them.

B.Choice: “No one has ever done that before; some thought it was impossible.”

C.Choice: Kip spoke up, “I guess this means that you’d rather listen to the radio than go to the diamond to play baseball with your teammates.”

D.Choice: “We learned that in school last week.”

SubTopics: Draw conclusions, infer, and analyze by citing the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Choose the evidence that best supports each conclusion.

A:“If we keep practicing, I’m sure we ca.Choice: 2:Patrick is extremely confident in his and his team’s abilities.

C:“This achievement is a testament to Li.Choice: 1:John has a high interest in and an understanding of science.

SubTopics: Analyze how specific word choices and sentence structures contribute to meaning and tone.
Content: Read the sentences from the passage.
:ibox:Before they could knock, John opened the door and shouted so the entire neighborhood could hear. “He did it! Charles Lindbergh landed in Paris, France, early this morning!”
How do the sentences change the tone of the overall passage?

A.Choice: from relaxed to excited

B.Choice: from indifferent to frantic

C.Choice: from determined to wishful

D.Choice: from confused to authoritative

SubTopics: Draw conclusions, infer, and analyze by citing the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Choose the sentence that BEST supports how John’s attitude toward Charles Lindbergh differs from his friends’.

:MC-A: “Listen, I have nothing against practice,” John said, “but Lindbergh’s achievement is historic. :MC-B: More than a hundred thousand people were waiting for him to land in Paris. :MC-C: I imagine the U.S. ambassador in France even showed up for the occasion. :MC-D: The announcer on the radio said that once the propeller on Lucky Lindy’s airplane stopped rotating, he was immediately surrounded by thousands of well-wishers.”

SubTopics: Analyze how word choice and sentence structure contribute to meaning and tone.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:ibox:First, biologists whisked 16 of the survivors to safety.
How does the use of the word “whisked” contribute to the tone of the sentence?

A.Choice: It creates a confident tone.

B.Choice: It suggests an urgent tone.

C.Choice: It creates a respectful tone.

D.Choice: It suggests an annoyed tone.

SubTopics: Analyze how an author's choice concerning a text's organization or overall structure contributes to meaning.
Content: How does the author’s inclusion of the section “A Hopping Head Start” contribute to the meaning of the passage?

A.Choice: It explains why predators are able to easily capture the pygmy rabbits in their Washington habitat.

B.Choice: It supports the idea that the Idaho species of rabbit helped to make the pygmy rabbits stronger.

C.Choice: It indicates how the pygmy rabbits function within a delicate ecosystem made of plants and animals.

D.Choice: It describes in detail why efforts to help the pygmy rabbits survive in the wild have been successful so far.

SubTopics: Draw conclusions, infer, and analyze by citing the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which sentences from the passage BEST support the conclusion that human actions have negatively impacted the pygmy rabbit population? Choose THREE answers.

A.Choice: For thousands of years, these tiny rabbits lived large here.

B.Choice: They cleared vast areas of sagebrush to plant wheat.

C.Choice: Their cattle trampled the soil, compacting it and making it harder to burrow.

D.Choice: Cheatgrass, an invasive grass accidentally brought from Europe and Asia, overran the ecosystem...

E.Choice: They fenced in two enclosures of sagebrush in the rabbit’s native habitat.

F.Choice: Scientists added plastic dog houses for even more protection, put up netting...

G.Choice: About once a month, biologists captured a few, tagged them with tracking devices, and released them...

SubTopics: Explain the central/main idea(s) of a text and analyze its development over the course of a text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Which statement BEST expresses a central idea of the passage?

A.Choice: Scientists are trying to increase the population of the nearly extinct Columbia Basin pygmy rabbit.

B.Choice: The Columbia Basin pygmy rabbit is the smallest rabbit species to inhabit the North American continent.

C.Choice: Scientists have discovered that the Columbia Basin pygmy rabbit helps to loosen soil when it digs burrows.

D.Choice: The Columbia Basin pygmy rabbit is able to survive in an environment with hot summers and cold winters.

Content: Which statement BEST explains how the author develops the idea in part A?

A.Choice: by describing how cattle affect the soil in the areas pygmy rabbits inhabit

B.Choice: by describing the efforts to breed pygmy rabbits and to offer them protection once the rabbits are released back into the wild

C.Choice: by revealing the average daily temperatures in eastern Washington state that pygmy rabbits have to endure

D.Choice: by showing how other animals in eastern Washington state currently compete with pygmy rabbits for food and shelter

SubTopics: Interpret visual elements of a text including those from different media and draw conclusions from them (when applicable).
Content: Based on the table at the end of the passage, how does the desert cottontail rabbit compare to the Columbia Basin pygmy rabbit?

A.Choice: The desert cottontail rabbit is much smaller than the Columbia Basin pygmy rabbit.

B.Choice: The desert cottontail rabbit lives in fewer states than the Columbia Basin pygmy rabbit.

C.Choice: The desert cottontail rabbit has a more diverse diet than the Columbia Basin pygmy rabbit.

D.Choice: The desert cottontail rabbit has completely different predators than the Columbia Basin pygmy rabbit.

SubTopics: Analyze how specific word choices and sentence structures contribute to meaning and tone.
Content: How does the author’s word choice in the first paragraph contribute to the tone of the passage?

A.Choice: Sad, gloomy language shows Heather’s immature attitude.

B.Choice: Poetic language emphasizes Heather’s affection for her mother.

C.Choice: Strong, negative language establishes Heather’s irritation about her situation.

D.Choice: Humorous language understates Heather’s sudden nervousness about finding a project.

SubTopics: Draw conclusions, infer, and analyze by citing the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Read the inferences in the chart. Choose the evidence from the passage that MOST STRONGLY supports each inference.

A:She grumbled to her mother, “The schoo.Choice: 2:Heather wishes to be a mentor to others in her school.

B:Mom quickly agreed. “Why don’t we walk.Choice: 1:Heather’s mom is supportive of her daughter.

SubTopics: Analyze how specific word choices and sentence structures contribute to meaning and tone.
Content: Read the paragraph from the passage.

:ibox:	Three days later the volunteer squad had grown to fifteen people of all ages from all across the area, and news of the unusual stick fort traveled quickly with many curious community members stopping by to chat about it. Heather and Ken cheerfully answered questions and guided the newcomers in the building process. By the end of the day, the fort was complete, and the local newspaper crew arrived to photograph the incredible stick fort and the volunteers who had so graciously built it.
How does the author’s description of Heather’s day contribute to the tone of the passage?

A.Choice: It emphasizes Heather’s success, suggesting why the librarian offers her another job.

B.Choice: It highlights why Heather is excited about volunteering, relieving the tension of her earlier solemn mood.

C.Choice: It focuses attention on the many friendships Heather forms with others, explaining why she seeks several volunteer experiences.

D.Choice: It details the process Heather’s team follows to finish the project, showing that the community values her organizational skills.

SubTopics: Using appropriate text, determine the theme(s) of a text and analyze its development over the course of a text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Which statement BEST describes a theme in the passage?

A.Choice: People are likely to help others if they are asked to do so.

B.Choice: Following the advice of others is an important step in growing up.

C.Choice: It is important to trust that family members will be loyal to one another.

D.Choice: Investing time and energy in a project often leads to more possibilities.

Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST supports the answer to part A?

A.Choice: Heather sighed and opened the local newspaper, scanning each page for opportunities she hadn’t already read online.

B.Choice: Heather and Mom put on work gloves and dived into the tasks.

C.Choice: “You found this opportunity, and I’m sure there will be another one coming your way.”

D.Choice: “Mom, it’s even better than I expected!”

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings using context, affixes, or reference materials.
Content: Choose the underlined word that suggests a feeling of excitement.

The city park was :MC-A: b͟u͟s͟t͟l͟i͟n͟g with activity when Heather and Mom :MC-B: a͟r͟r͟i͟v͟e͟d. Community members were :MC-C: w͟o͟r͟k͟i͟n͟g all around the park. “Over there,” a man said, :MC-D: g͟e͟s͟t͟u͟r͟i͟n͟g in Heather and Mom’s direction, “put those trash bags in the bed of the truck; then come help :MC-E: l͟i͟f͟t this fork-and-spoon sculpture and set it next to the oak tree.”

SubTopics: Approaching The Task As A Researcher
Content: A student is conducting research to gather support for his claim that a class on the basics of interpersonal communication and public speaking should be offered at his school.
Which source would give the student the MOST relevant information to use in his argument?

A.Choice: “Why Politicians Can Benefit from Acting Lessons,” an article in Time magazine

B.Choice: How to Become a Great Public Speaker, a book in the self-help section of the library

C.Choice: Great Speakers of the Twentieth Century, a documentary series on the public television channel

D.Choice: “Job Success Tied to Communication Skills,” a news release from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics

SubTopics: Approaching The Task As A Researcher
Content: A student has written a draft paragraph from his research on honeybees, but the paragraph is overly broad. Read the paragraph.

:ibox:The honeybees that buzz around flowers are worker bees that gather nectar. Honeybees suck up nectar from plants and store it until they can deposit it into the hive. There, the nectar is transformed into food. Honeybees also play an important role in the plant reproduction process. As they travel from flower to flower, they carry grains of pollen.
The student wants to develop the three topics in his paragraph by finding more specific information he can use to write three additional paragraphs about honeybees.
Read the topics in the table and the research questions. Match the research questions with the topic each question supports. Use each question ONE time.

A:What is pollen?.Choice: 3:how the honeybee assists in plant reproduction

D:What types of fruits do honeybees help.Choice: 3:how the honeybee assists in plant reproduction

SubTopics: Approaching The Task As A Researcher
Content: Read the information from a source.

:ibox:One of the most important differences between the British and the American colonists was the question of titles of nobility. In England, nobles had great power because their titles went back for generations, and their families held great estates and wealth. In England, people were either royalty, nobility, or commoners. This was not the case in America. In the colonies, no one cared about noble titles. Instead, people were judged by their skills. Were you a blacksmith? Did you know how to build a house? Were you strong enough to cut timber and clear fields? P͟e͟o͟p͟l͟e͟ ͟h͟a͟d͟ ͟t͟o͟ ͟b͟e͟ ͟v͟e͟r͟y͟ ͟s͟e͟l͟f͟-͟r͟e͟l͟i͟a͟n͟t͟ ͟t͟o͟ ͟l͟i͟v͟e͟ ͟i͟n͟ ͟t͟h͟e͟ ͟N͟e͟w͟ ͟W͟o͟r͟l͟d͟. The people who rose to leadership in government in the colonies were not the descendants of nobility or royalty. Instead, they were the hardest working and most successful property owners, business people, shipbuilders, or craftspeople. T͟h͟e͟y͟ ͟d͟i͟d͟ ͟n͟o͟t͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟ ͟a͟n͟s͟w͟e͟r͟i͟n͟g͟ ͟t͟o͟ ͟a͟ ͟k͟i͟n͟g͟ ͟t͟h͟o͟u͟s͟a͟n͟d͟s͟ ͟o͟f͟ ͟m͟i͟l͟e͟s͟ ͟a͟w͟a͟y͟.
Which sentence avoids plagiarism and is the BEST paraphrase of the underlined sentences from the source?

A.Choice: People needed to be very self-reliant to live in the New World, and they did not like answering to a king.

B.Choice: These self-reliant people did not like answering to a king from thousands of miles away.

C.Choice: These self-reliant people disliked obeying policies and orders of British royalty.

D.Choice: People had to be self-reliant, and they did not like to answer to a king.

SubTopics: Approaching The Task As A Researcher
Content: A student is writing an argumentative report to support her claim that George Washington’s leadership helped win the Revolutionary War.
Which sources would provide the MOST relevant information for the student to use in her report? Choose TWO answers.

A.Choice: a historical map of Washington’s travels

B.Choice: a short story about Washington’s early life

C.Choice: a letter from Washington to his soldiers at Valley Forge

D.Choice: a thorough analysis of Washington’s victory at Yorktown

E.Choice: a biography of Washington that focuses on his presidency

F.Choice: a documentary that explains Washington’s feelings about alliances

SubTopics: Approaching The Task As A Researcher
Content: A student is writing a research report about sleep. Read the student’s research report plan.

:box:Research Report Plan

Topic: Getting enough sleep
Audience: Classmates and teacher
Purpose: To show that adequate sleep is important to brain health
Research Question: How does sleep benefit our brains?
Read the paragraph from a source. Circle the sentence containing information that best supports the student’s claim.

:MC-A: Americans have a sleep deficit of about two hours per night on average. :MC-B: That means most of us sleep for six hours when we should be sleeping at least eight hours. :MC-C: During REM (rapid eye movement) sleep, the latter stage of the sleep cycle, neural transmitters responsible for learning, remembering, problem-solving, and performing tasks are replenished. :MC-D: Sleeping fewer hours per night interferes with this important updating process in our brains. :MC-E: We are less productive because we get less sleep.

SubTopics: Introduce the topic, maintain a clear focus throughout the text, and provide a conclusion that follows from the text. Add or delete content and change organization to achieve the writer's purpose.
Content: :ibox:Put a cough drop into your mouth and immediately the stinging, minty, frosty sensation of eucalyptus fills your nose and throat, making it easier to breathe without coughing. The eucalyptus in cough drops comes from the leaves of the eucalyptus tree. These trees are most abundant in Australia, thriving in all of its varied climates. Eucalyptus oil is distilled from the leaves of the tree and can be used as a decongestant, disinfectant, and deodorizer.
Which sentence would make the BEST conclusion for the paragraph?

A.Choice: Because of its many uses, eucalyptus oil is a major export for Australia.

B.Choice: As eucalyptus trees grow older, the shape of their leaves changes.

C.Choice: Koalas love to climb tall eucalyptus trees and chew the leaves.

D.Choice: Australia is a leading producer of eucalyptus cough drops.

SubTopics: Choose precise language and make syntactical choices appropriate for the style, task, and audience.
Content: Read the excerpt from a student’s narrative.

:ibox:When Cecily entered from stage right, she was immediately struck by the brightness of the spotlights. She _________ into the lights but then remembered to stay in character and relaxed her face. She turned her face slightly away from the direct glare so that she was looking at the other characters on the stage, and not into the audience.
Choose the MOST precise word to complete the sentence.

A.Choice: gazed

B.Choice: looked

C.Choice: peeped

D.Choice: squinted

SubTopics: Acknowledge new information expressed by others including those presented in diverse media and, when warranted, qualify or justify their own views in light of evidence presented.
Content: Read the sentence from the presentation.
:ibox:Scientists have discovered that handwriting can create powerful connections in the brain.
Based on the presentation, what would psychologist Paul Bloom MOST LIKELY credit for the “powerful connections” created by handwriting? Choose TWO answers.

A.Choice: improved memory

B.Choice: increased concentration

C.Choice: production of higher-quality work

D.Choice: raised awareness of the most important details

SubTopics: Acknowledge new information expressed by others including those presented in diverse media and, when warranted, qualify or justify their own views in light of evidence presented.
Content: Which counterargument to learning handwriting does the speaker acknowledge?

A.Choice: Using a keyboard can cause distractions.

B.Choice: Electronic devices provide more benefits.

C.Choice: Keyboarding is the primary method of written communication.

D.Choice: Learning handwriting is too time consuming for schools to teach.

SubTopics: Delineate a speaker’s argument and claims, evaluating reasoning and sufficiency of evidence in order to pose questions that connect the ideas of several speakers and respond to others' questions and comments with relevant evidence, observations, and ideas.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
What is the primary claim the speaker makes about the value of handwriting?

A.Choice: It is a worthwhile skill to master.

B.Choice: It is necessary for many areas of life.

C.Choice: It creates more opportunities for learning.

D.Choice: It provides a way to increase performance.

Content: Which detail from the presentation BEST supports the answer to part A?

A.Choice: Handwriting offers benefits that keyboarding does not.

B.Choice: You might need to use handwriting to take notes for your boss.

C.Choice: Adults can benefit from keyboarding as much as children and teens.

D.Choice: Studies have been conducted that test the way handwriting impacts students.

SubTopics: Delineate a speaker’s argument and claims, evaluating reasoning and sufficiency of evidence in order to pose questions that connect the ideas of several speakers and respond to others' questions and comments with relevant evidence, observations, and ideas.
Content: Which reason does the speaker give for why “mental connections are more difficult to form with keyboarding”?

A.Choice: Keyboarding creates too many distractions.

B.Choice: Keyboarding is not required for some everyday tasks.

C.Choice: Keyboarding is used so frequently that learning becomes ineffective.

D.Choice: Keyboarding does not activate a pathway between different parts of the brain.

SubTopics: Delineate a speaker’s argument and claims, evaluating reasoning and sufficiency of evidence in order to pose questions that connect the ideas of several speakers and respond to others' questions and comments with relevant evidence, observations, and ideas.
Content: Which claim by the speaker lacks sufficient support?

A.Choice: Protecting the statues is of utmost importance.

B.Choice: Lord Elgin did not legally purchase the statues.

C.Choice: Determining ownership of artifacts is often difficult.

D.Choice: Many of the artifacts of the Parthenon did not survive.

SubTopics: Delineate a speaker’s argument and claims, evaluating reasoning and sufficiency of evidence in order to pose questions that connect the ideas of several speakers and respond to others' questions and comments with relevant evidence, observations, and ideas.
Content: Which claim does the speaker make about the preservation of the Elgin Marbles?

A.Choice: The ability to safeguard the statues is the determining factor for which country should keep them.

B.Choice: Using new procedures to clean and maintain the statues is essential in restoring them.

C.Choice: Protecting the statues from harm is a challenging process.

D.Choice: Harsh chemicals and sandpaper can destroy the statues.

SubTopics: Delineate a speaker’s argument and claims, evaluating reasoning and sufficiency of evidence in order to pose questions that connect the ideas of several speakers and respond to others' questions and comments with relevant evidence, observations, and ideas.
Content: Identify whether each point of view belongs to England or Greece.

SubTopics: Acknowledge new information expressed by others including those presented in diverse media and, when warranted, qualify or justify their own views in light of evidence presented.
Content: With which statement would the speaker MOST LIKELY agree?

A.Choice: England should keep the statues because they were legally obtained.

B.Choice: Greece should keep the statues because they originated at the Parthenon.

C.Choice: The country with the best museums should keep the statues because they should be displayed properly.

D.Choice: The country that can provide the best protection for the statues should keep them because they should be kept safe.
